Ellipsoid method

Posted on 2020-02-20 Edited on 2022-06-21

Ellipsoid method is a weakly polynomial algorithm for solving linear programming.
The preliminary version was introduced by the Russian mathematician Shor in 1977 for general convex optimization problems.
Then it was applied to linear programming by Khachyan in 1979 [1].
Before interior point method, it was the first polynomial time algorithm for LP.

Feasibility implies Optimality

Now, consider the primal LP:

P:max⁡cTxs.t.Ax≤bx≥0 \mathcal{P}: \qquad \begin{aligned} &\max &c^T x & \\ &s.t. &Ax \le b & \\ & & x \ge 0 & \end{aligned} P:​maxs.t.​cTxAx≤bx≥0​​

whose dual is given by

D:min⁡yTb  s.t.yTA≥cTy≥0   \mathcal{D}: \qquad \begin{aligned} &\min &y^Tb \ \ & \\ &s.t. &y^TA \ge c^T & \\ & &y \ge 0 \ \ & \end{aligned} D:​mins.t.​yTb  yTA≥cTy≥0  ​​

The ellipsoid does not optimize the primal directly.
Instead, it try to return a feasible point (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) that satisfies the following constraints:

cTx=yTbAx≤bx≥0yTA≥cTy≥0  \begin{aligned} c^T x &= y^Tb & \\ Ax &\le b & \\ x &\ge 0 & \\ y^TA &\ge c^T & \\ y &\ge 0 \ \ & \end{aligned} cTxAxxyTAy​=yTb≤b≥0≥cT≥0  ​​

By weak duality, if such point exists, then xxx is the optimal solution for the primal program. (Note that, if there is no feasible point for the third program, the primal could be either infeasible or unbounded.)

Ellipsoid

Ellipsoid is a unit ball that has been squashed or stretched along orthogonal directions. We illustrate this by an example in two dimension. The following picture shows an ellipse obtained by enlarging the unit ball by a facto of 222 along the v1v_1v1​ direction and squashing it ball by half along the v2v_2v2​ direction, where v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​ constitute an orthogonal base.

It is equivalent to first squash or stretch the ball along the directions of e1,e2e_1, e_2e1​,e2​,

then rotate the resulting ellipsoid to corresponding orthogonal directions.

The rotation can be done by left multiplying an orthogonal matrix

V=[v1,v2]V = [v_1, v_2] V=[v1​,v2​]

where v1,v2v_1, v_2v1​,v2​ are the orthogonal base for which the squash and stretch are performed.

To recover the unit ball, we can first perform the reverse rotation:

x←VTxx \leftarrow V^T x x←VTx

followed by a reverse scaling:

x←[1/22]x x \leftarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & \\ & 2 \end{bmatrix} x x←[1/2​2​]x

Note that the reverse rotation is represented by matrix VTV^TVT as VVT=IV V^T = IVVT=I.
Therefore, the ellipsoid is denoted as

([1/22]VTx)T([1/22]VTx)≤1 \left( \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & \\ & 2 \end{bmatrix} V^T x \right)^T \left( \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & \\ & 2 \end{bmatrix} V^T x \right) \le 1 ([1/2​2​]VTx)T([1/2​2​]VTx)≤1

That is

xT(V[1/22]2VT)x≤1 x^T \left( V \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & \\ & 2 \end{bmatrix}^2 V^T \right) x \le 1 xT(V[1/2​2​]2VT)x≤1

In general, an ellipsoid is represented by

E(s,P)={x:(x−s)TP−1(x−s)≤1} E(s, P) = \{ x : (x - s)^T P^{-1} (x - s) \le 1\} E(s,P)={x:(x−s)TP−1(x−s)≤1}

where s∈Rns \in \mathbb{R}^ns∈Rn is the center of the ellipsoid and PPP is a positive semi-definite matrix.

Recall that a positive semi-definite matrix PPP can be rewritten as

P=VΣVT P = V \Sigma V^T P=VΣVT

and

P−1=VΣ−1VT P^{-1} = V \Sigma^{-1} V^T P−1=VΣ−1VT

where VVV is an orthogonal matrix and Σ\SigmaΣ is a diagonal matrix.
Geometrically, VVV are the directions and Σ\sqrt \SigmaΣ​ are the ratios of the squashes or stretches.
If we define B=VΣB = V \sqrt \SigmaB=VΣ​, then BT=ΣVTB^T = \sqrt \Sigma V^TBT=Σ​VT, B−1=Σ−1VTB^{-1} = \sqrt \Sigma^{-1} V^TB−1=Σ​−1VT and P=BBTP = B B^TP=BBT, P−1=(B−1)TB−1P^{-1} = (B^{-1} )^T B^{-1}P−1=(B−1)TB−1.

The representation can be viewed as merely a recipe for converting the ellipsoid back to the unit ball:

  1. First perform a translation x←(x−s)x \leftarrow (x - s)x←(x−s) so that the center of the ellipsoid is now the center.

  2. Rotate the ellipsoid, such that its axes are aligned with e1,e2,...,ene_1, e_2, ..., e_ne1​,e2​,...,en​. This is done by multiplying the matrix VTV^TVT: x←VTxx \leftarrow V^T xx←VTx.

  3. Squash or stretch along the axes e1,e2,...,ene_1, e_2, ..., e_ne1​,e2​,...,en​: x←Σ−1xx \leftarrow \sqrt \Sigma^{-1} xx←Σ​−1x.

  4. Therefore, the linear transformation for the recovery is

x←B−1(x−s) x \leftarrow B^{-1} (x - s) x←B−1(x−s)

Conversely, E(s,P)=E(s,VΣΣVT)E(s, P) = E(s, V \sqrt \Sigma \sqrt \Sigma V^T)E(s,P)=E(s,VΣ​Σ​VT) tells us how to get the ellipsoid from the unit ball:

  1. Scale unit ball along the axes e1,e2,..,ene_1, e_2, .., e_ne1​,e2​,..,en​ by factors that Σ1,1,Σ2,2,...,Σn,n\sqrt \Sigma_{1, 1}, \sqrt \Sigma_{2, 2}, ..., \sqrt \Sigma_{n, n}Σ​1,1​,Σ​2,2​,...,Σ​n,n​.

  2. Rotate the ellipsoid by matrix VVV.

  3. Move the ellipsoid by sss.

That is, x←VΣy+sx \leftarrow V \sqrt \Sigma y + sx←VΣ​y+s takes the unit ball {y:yTy≤1}\{ y : y^T y \le 1 \}{y:yTy≤1} to the corresponding ellipsoid {x:(x−s)TVΣ−1VT(x−s)≤1}\{ x : (x - s)^T V \Sigma^{-1} V^T (x - s) \le 1 \}{x:(x−s)TVΣ−1VT(x−s)≤1}.

Goal

Now return to our discussion of ellipsoid method.
Without lose of generality, we consider only the following problem:

Given F={x:Ax≤b}F = \{x : Ax \le b\}F={x:Ax≤b}, output any x∈Fx \in Fx∈F or report F=∅F = \emptysetF=∅, where A∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈RmA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}, x \in \mathbb{R}^n, b \in \mathbb{R}^mA∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈Rm.

We assume further that

  1. ∃R∈R\exists R \in \mathbb{R}∃R∈R, F⊆B(0,R)F \subseteq B(0, R)F⊆B(0,R).
    Besides, if F≠∅F \neq \emptysetF=∅, ∃r∈R\exists r \in \mathbb{R}∃r∈R, and t∈Rnt \in \mathbb{R}^nt∈Rn, s.t., B(t,r)⊆FB(t, r) \subseteq FB(t,r)⊆F.
    Here B(0,R)={x:∥x∥2≤R}B(0, R) = \{ x : \Vert x\Vert_2 \le R \}B(0,R)={x:∥x∥2​≤R} and B(t,r)={x:∥x−t∥2≤r}B(t, r) = \{ x : \Vert x - t\Vert_2 \le r \}B(t,r)={x:∥x−t∥2​≤r}.

  2. Separation Oracle: Given a vertex s∈Rns \in \mathbb{R}^ns∈Rn, the separation oracle is a mechanism that asserts

    • either s∈Fs \in Fs∈F
    • or s∉Fs \notin Fs∈/F and returns a direction (which is a unit vector) d∈Rnd \in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn, such that dTs≥dTxd^T s \ge d^T xdTs≥dTx for ∀x∈F\forall x \in F∀x∈F.

The first assumption says that FFF is neither too “large” nor too “small”.
Note that B(t,r)⊆FB(t, r) \subseteq FB(t,r)⊆F also implies that FFF has full dimension.

For LP, the separation is straightforward to implement: we just check whether As≤bAs \le bAs≤b.
If so, then s∈Fs \in Fs∈F. Otherwise, ∃i∈[m]\exists i \in [m]∃i∈[m], such that the ithi^{th}ith constraint is violated: (As)i>bi(A s)_i > b_i(As)i​>bi​. Just return dT=Ai,⋅d^T = A_{i, \cdot}dT=Ai,⋅​.

Question to ponder: the feasible region of an LP may not satisfy the first assumption?
It is possible to reduce it to one satisfying the first assumption?

The Algorithm

The algorithm begins with a special ellipsoid E0=B(0,R)E_0 = B(0, R)E0​=B(0,R).
At each step, it queries the separation oracle and generates a smaller ellipsoid (with reduced volume).
If FFF is not empty, the ellipsoid at each step is guaranteed to contain it.
The algorithm stops before the volume of the ellipsoid decreases below $ \mathtt{vol} (B(t, r))$.

The algorithmic flow is shown below:

  1. i=0i = 0i=0.

  2. E0=B(0,R)E_0 = B(0, R)E0​=B(0,R).

  3. While vol(Ei(si,Pi))≥vol(B(t,r))\mathtt{vol} (E_i(s_i, P_i)) \ge \mathtt{vol} (B(t, r))vol(Ei​(si​,Pi​))≥vol(B(t,r)):

  4. \qquad if si∈Fs_i \in Fsi​∈F, output sis_isi​.

  5. \qquad else,

  6. \qquad \qquad Obtain a direction did_idi​, s.t., diTsi≥diTxd_i^T s_i \ge d_i^T xdiT​si​≥diT​x
    for x∈Fx \in Fx∈F*.

  7. \qquad \qquad Calculate a ellipsoid Ei+1⊃Ei∩{x:diTsi≥diTx}E_{i + 1} \supset E_{i} \cap \{x : d_i^T s_i \ge d_i^T x \}Ei+1​⊃Ei​∩{x:diT​si​≥diT​x}.

  8. \qquad \qquad i←i+1i \leftarrow i + 1i←i+1.

  9. Output F=∅F = \emptysetF=∅.

For the one dimension case, it is nothing more than a variant of binary search.

Bounding the Number of Iterations

The main result that characterizes the running time is

Theorem. It is guaranteed that for each iii,

vol(Ei+1)vol(Ei)≤exp⁡(−12(n+1)). \frac{ \mathtt{vol} ( E_{i + 1} ) } { \mathtt{vol} (E_i) } \le \exp \left( -\frac{1}{2 (n + 1) } \right). vol(Ei​)vol(Ei+1​)​≤exp(−2(n+1)1​).

Corollary. The number of iterations of the ellipsoid method is bounded by

2n(n+1)ln⁡Rr. 2n(n + 1) \ln \frac{R}{r}. 2n(n+1)lnrR​.

To simplify the notation further, we write Ei=E(s,P)E_i = E(s, P)Ei​=E(s,P), di=dd_i = ddi​=d and Ei+1=E(s′,P′)E_{i + 1} = E(s', P')Ei+1​=E(s′,P′). The key lemma for the theorem is:

Lemma. Given an ellipsoid E(s,P)={x∈Rn:(x−s)TP−1(x−s)≤1}E(s, P) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n : (x - s)^T P^{-1} (x - s) \le 1\}E(s,P)={x∈Rn:(x−s)TP−1(x−s)≤1} and the half space H(s,d)={x∈Rn:dT(x−s)≤0}H(s, d) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n : d^T (x - s)\le 0 \}H(s,d)={x∈Rn:dT(x−s)≤0}, we can find an ellipsoid E(s′,P′)E(s', P')E(s′,P′), such that

  1. E(s′,P′)E(s', P')E(s′,P′) contains the intersection of E(s,P)E(s, P)E(s,P) and H(s,d)H(s, d)H(s,d) :

E(c,P)∩H(s,d). E(c, P) \cap H(s, d). E(c,P)∩H(s,d).

  1. The volume of E(s′,P′)E(s', P')E(s′,P′) is at most exp⁡(−12(n+1))\exp \left( -\frac{1}{2 (n + 1) } \right)exp(−2(n+1)1​) times that of E(s,P)E(s, P)E(s,P).

In particular, s′s's′ and P′P'P′ is given by

s′=s−1n+1PddTPdP′=n2n2−1(P−2n+1PddTPd(PddTPd)T) \begin{aligned} s' &= s - \frac{1}{n + 1} \frac{P d}{\sqrt{d^T P d} } \\ P' &= \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} \left( P - \frac{2}{n + 1} \frac{Pd}{\sqrt{d^T P d} } \left( \frac{Pd}{\sqrt{d^T P d} } \right)^T \right) \end{aligned} s′P′​=s−n+11​dTPd​Pd​=n2−1n2​(P−n+12​dTPd​Pd​(dTPd​Pd​)T)​

Proof.
The transformation y=B−1(x−s)y = B^{-1} (x - s)y=B−1(x−s) maps E(s,P)E(s, P)E(s,P) to E(0，I)E(0，I)E(0，I), and

{x∈Rn:dTB(B−1(x−s))≤0} \{x \in R^n: d^T B (B^{-1} (x - s)) \le 0\} {x∈Rn:dTB(B−1(x−s))≤0}

to

H(0,BTd)={y∈Rn:dTBy≤0}. H(0, B^T d) = \{y \in R^n: d^T B y \le 0\}. H(0,BTd)={y∈Rn:dTBy≤0}.

Let

e′=BTddTBBTd=BTddTPde' = \frac{B^T d}{\sqrt{d^T B B^T d} } = \frac{B^T d}{\sqrt{d^T P d} } e′=dTBBTd​BTd​=dTPd​BTd​

so that H(0,BTd)H(0, B^Td)H(0,BTd) is equivalent to H(0,e′)H(0, e')H(0,e′).

It suffices to find an ellipsoid that contains E(0,I)∩H(0,e′)E(0, I) \cap H(0, e')E(0,I)∩H(0,e′). Then applying the reverse transformation x=By+sx = By + sx=By+s will give us an ellipsoid that contains E(s,P)∩H(s,d)E(s, P) \cap H(s, d)E(s,P)∩H(s,d).

We can further reduce the problem to finding an ellipsoid that covers E(0,I)∩H(0,e1)E(0, I) \cap H(0, e_1)E(0,I)∩H(0,e1​) as we can recover the ellipsoid by rotating e1e_1e1​ to e′e'e′.

Claim.
The ellipsoid that covers E(0,I)∩H(0,e1)E(0,I) \cap H(0, e_1)E(0,I)∩H(0,e1​) is given by

E(−1n+1e1,n2n2−1(I−2n+1e1e1T)) E \left( -\frac{1}{n + 1}e_1, \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} \left( I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e_1 e_1^T \right) \right) E(−n+11​e1​,n2−1n2​(I−n+12​e1​e1T​))

and has minimum volume exp⁡(−12(n+1))\exp ( -\frac{1}{2(n + 1)} )exp(−2(n+1)1​).

To under the ellipsoid, we check how it transforms the unit ball to an ellipsoid:

  1. It squashes the ball along the e1e_1e1​ axis, by a factor of n2n2−1n−1n+1=nn+1\sqrt{ \frac{n^2} {n^2 - 1} \frac{n - 1} {n + 1} } = \frac{n}{ n + 1 }n2−1n2​n+1n−1​​=n+1n​.

  2. Then it stretches all other directions e2,e3,...,ene_2, e_3, ..., e_ne2​,e3​,...,en​ by a factor of n2n2−1\sqrt \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1}n2−1n2​​.

  3. Finally, move the center of the ellipsoid to −1n+1e1-\frac{1}{n + 1}e_1−n+11​e1​.

Note that the ellipsoid has volume

(1−1n+1)(1+1n2−1)(n−1)/2≤exp⁡(−1n+1+1n2−1(n−1)/2)=exp⁡(−12(n+1)). \begin{aligned} \left(1 - \frac{1}{n + 1} \right) \left( 1 + \frac{1}{n^2 -1} \right)^{(n - 1) / 2} &\le \exp \left( - \frac{1}{n + 1} + \frac{1}{n^2 -1} (n - 1) / 2 \right) \\ &= \exp \left( - \frac{1}{2(n + 1)} \right). \end{aligned} (1−n+11​)(1+n2−11​)(n−1)/2​≤exp(−n+11​+n2−11​(n−1)/2)=exp(−2(n+1)1​).​

This is also the ratio of the ellipsoid over that of the unit ball, whose value is 1.

Before we prove the claim, we show how to transform the ellipsoid back to E(s′,P′)E(s', P')E(s′,P′) that covers E(s,P)∩H(s,d)E(s, P) \cap H(s, d)E(s,P)∩H(s,d).
First, by symmetry, the ellipsoid that covers E(0,I)∩H(0,e′)E(0, I) \cap H(0, e')E(0,I)∩H(0,e′) is given by

E(−1n+1e′,n2n2−1(I−2n+1e′(e′)T)) E \left( -\frac{1}{n + 1}e', \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} \left( I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e' (e')^T \right) \right) E(−n+11​e′,n2−1n2​(I−n+12​e′(e′)T))

Applying the mapping By+s=xB y + s = xBy+s=x:

E(−1n+1e′,n2n2−1(I−2n+1e′(e′)T))⟶E(s−1n+1BTe′,n2n2−1B(I−2n+1e′(e′)T)BT). E \left( -\frac{1}{n + 1} e', \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} \left( I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e' (e')^T \right) \right) \\ \longrightarrow E \left( s - \frac{1}{n + 1} B^T e', \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} B \left( I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e' (e')^T \right) B^T \right). E(−n+11​e′,n2−1n2​(I−n+12​e′(e′)T))⟶E(s−n+11​BTe′,n2−1n2​B(I−n+12​e′(e′)T)BT).

As linear transformation preserves the ratio of volumes, the ratio of the volume of the final ellipsoid over that of E(s,P)E(s, P)E(s,P) is also exp⁡(−12(n+1))\exp(- \frac{1}{2 (n + 1)} )exp(−2(n+1)1​).

Question to ponder:

  1. Show that n2n2−1(I−2n+1e1e1T)\frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} (I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e_1 e_1^T)n2−1n2​(I−n+12​e1​e1T​) is positive definite.

  2. Show that (n2n2−1(I−2n+1e1e1T))−1=n2−1n2I+2n+2n2e1e1T\left( \frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} (I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e_1 e_1^T) \right)^{-1} = \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^2} I + \frac{2n + 2}{n^2} e_1 e_1^T(n2−1n2​(I−n+12​e1​e1T​))−1=n2n2−1​I+n22n+2​e1​e1T​.

  3. Show that n2n2−1B(I−2n+1e′(e′)T)BT\frac{n^2}{n^2 - 1} B (I - \frac{2}{n + 1}e' (e')^T) B^Tn2−1n2​B(I−n+12​e′(e′)T)BT is positive definite.

Proof of the Claim.
As both E(0,I)E(0,I)E(0,I) and H(0,e1)H(0, e_1)H(0,e1​) are symmetric to e1e_1e1​, so should the ellipsoid covering the intersection of them. Therefore it should be of the form

a1(x1−λ)+∑i=2naixi2≤1 a_1 (x_1 - \lambda) + \sum_{i = 2}^n a_i x_i^2 \le 1 a1​(x1​−λ)+i=2∑n​ai​xi2​≤1

where aia_iai​’s and λ\lambdaλ (0<λ<10 < \lambda < 10<λ<1) are the parameters to be determined. The goal is to minimize its volume:

1a1∏i=2n1aivol[E(0,I)]. \sqrt{\frac{1}{a_1} \prod_{i = 2}^n \frac{1}{a_i} } \mathtt{vol} [ E(0, I) ]. a1​1​i=2∏n​ai​1​​vol[E(0,I)].

where $ \mathtt{vol} [ E(0, I) ] = 1$ is the volume of unit ball in RnR^nRn. It is equivalent to maximize

a1∏i=2nai. a_1 \prod_{i = 2}^n a_i. a1​i=2∏n​ai​.

As the ellipsoid covers E(0,I)∩H(0,e1)E(0,I) \cap H(0, e_1)E(0,I)∩H(0,e1​) and should has as small volume as possible, the points eie_iei​ (i=1,2,...,ni = 1, 2, ..., ni=1,2,...,n) should be on its boundary. Therefore,

a1(1−λ)2+∑i=2nai02=1→a1(1−λ)2=1a1(0−λ)2+ai12=1→ai=1−a1λ2∀i=2,3,...,n \begin{aligned} a_1 (1 - \lambda)^2 + \sum_{i = 2}^n a_i 0^2 &= 1 &\rightarrow a_1(1 - \lambda)^2 = 1 &\\ a_1 (0 - \lambda)^2 + a_i 1^2 &= 1 &\rightarrow a_i = 1 - a_1 \lambda^2 &\quad \forall i = 2, 3, ..., n \\ \end{aligned} a1​(1−λ)2+i=2∑n​ai​02a1​(0−λ)2+ai​12​=1=1​→a1​(1−λ)2=1→ai​=1−a1​λ2​∀i=2,3,...,n​

Replacing aia_iai​ with 1−a1λ21 - a_1 \lambda^21−a1​λ2 and then a1a_1a1​ with 1(1−λ)2\frac{1}{(1 - \lambda)^2}(1−λ)21​, the goal becomes

max⁡1(1−λ)2[1−λ2(1−λ)2]n−1 \max \quad \frac{1}{(1 - \lambda)^2} \left[ 1 - \frac{\lambda^2}{(1 - \lambda)^2} \right]^{n - 1} max(1−λ)21​[1−(1−λ)2λ2​]n−1

Substitute 11−λ\frac{1}{1 - \lambda}1−λ1​ by a variable x>1x > 1x>1, and let

f≐x2[1−(x−1)2]n−1 f \doteq x^2 [1 - (x - 1)^2]^{n - 1} f≐x2[1−(x−1)2]n−1

Its derivative is

f′=2x[1−(x−1)2]n−1−2(n−1)(x−1)x2[1−(x−1)2]n−2 f' = 2x [1 - (x - 1)^2]^{n - 1} - 2 (n - 1)(x - 1) x^2 [1 - (x - 1)^2]^{n - 2} f′=2x[1−(x−1)2]n−1−2(n−1)(x−1)x2[1−(x−1)2]n−2

Setting the derivative to zero, we obtain

[1−(x−1)2]−(n−1)(x−1)x=0⇒1−x2+2x−1−(n−1)x2+(n−1)x=0⇒−nx2+(n+1)x=0⇒x=n+1n \begin{aligned} &[1 - (x - 1)^2] - (n - 1)(x - 1)x = 0 \\ &\Rightarrow 1 - x^2 + 2x - 1- (n -1 )x^2 + (n -1 )x = 0 \\ &\Rightarrow - n x^2 + (n + 1) x = 0 \\ &\Rightarrow x = \frac{n + 1}{n} \end{aligned} ​[1−(x−1)2]−(n−1)(x−1)x=0⇒1−x2+2x−1−(n−1)x2+(n−1)x=0⇒−nx2+(n+1)x=0⇒x=nn+1​​

It follows that a1=(n+1n)2a_1 = (\frac{n + 1}{n})^2a1​=(nn+1​)2, λ=1n+1\lambda = \frac{1}{n + 1}λ=n+11​ and ai=n2−1n2a_i = \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^2}ai​=n2n2−1​ for ∀i=2,3,...,n\forall i = 2, 3, ..., n∀i=2,3,...,n.

Reference

[1]. Michel X. Goemans, 7. Lecture notes on the ellipsoid algorithm, 18.433: Combinatorial Optimization, MIT

Determinant, Cross Product and Cramer's-Rule

Posted on 2020-02-18 Edited on 2020-04-21

Determinant

When studying linear algebra, the determinant function det⁡(⋅)\det(\cdot)det(⋅) is a horrifying subject. We try to give a friendly approach to it in this article.

I think it is the study of the volume of the parallelotope specified by v1,v2,...,vn∈Rnv_1, v_2, ... ,v_n \in \mathbb{R}^nv1​,v2​,...,vn​∈Rn that gives it away. The parallelotope is defined as the set

{∑i∈[n]λivi:λi∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]}\left\{ \sum_{i \in [n]} \lambda_i v_i : \lambda_i \in [0, 1], \forall i \in [n] \right\} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​i∈[n]∑​λi​vi​:λi​∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

Let’s denote f(v1,v2,...,vn):Rn×n→Rf(v_1, v_2, ... ,v_n) : \mathbb{R}^{n \times n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f(v1​,v2​,...,vn​):Rn×n→R the singed volume function, i.e., ∣f(v1,v2,...,vn)∣|f(v_1, v_2, ... ,v_n)|∣f(v1​,v2​,...,vn​)∣ gives the volume of the parallelotope. We will show how to determine the sign of fff later. At this point, we do not know how det⁡(⋅)\det(\cdot)det(⋅) is related to the volume. Therefore, we use the notation fff instead.

We show how to derive the formula of fff by its properties. The two key properties associated with volume are

  1. fff is multi-linear. Specially, it is a linear function in any dimension when other dimensions are fixed:

    • f(v1,v2,...,cvi,...,vn)=cf(v1,v2,...,vn)f(v_1, v_2, ..., cv_i, ... ,v_n)=cf(v_1, v_2, ... ,v_n)f(v1​,v2​,...,cvi​,...,vn​)=cf(v1​,v2​,...,vn​) for ∀i∈[n]\forall i \in [n]∀i∈[n] and c∈Rc \in \mathbb{R}c∈R. Geometrically, if we scale the iii-th vector viv_ivi​ by a factor ccc, then the volume of the parallelotope should change by the same factor.

      In the above example, when v2v_2v2​ is fixed, the area of the parallelogram is determined by its height, i.e., the projection of v1v_1v1​ to the orthogonal direction of v2v_2v2​. When v1v_1v1​ doubles, the length of its projection doubles.

    • f(v1,v2,...,vi+ui,...,vn)=f(v1,v2,...,vi,...,vn)+f(v1,v2,...,ui,...,vn)f(v_1, v_2, ..., v_i + u_i, ... ,v_n)= f(v_1, v_2, ..., v_i, ... ,v_n) + f(v_1, v_2, ..., u_i, ... ,v_n)f(v1​,v2​,...,vi​+ui​,...,vn​)=f(v1​,v2​,...,vi​,...,vn​)+f(v1​,v2​,...,ui​,...,vn​).

      In the above example, when v2v_2v2​ is fixed, the projection to the orthogonal direction of v2v_2v2​ are additive. In particular, denote P(v1)\mathcal{P}(v_1)P(v1​) the length of the projection of v1v_1v1​ to the orthogonal direction of v2v_2v2​. Similarly we define P(v2)\mathcal{P}(v_2)P(v2​) and P(v1+v2)\mathcal{P}(v_1 + v_2)P(v1​+v2​). Then

    P(v1+v2)=P(v1)+P(v2)\mathcal{P}(v_1 + v_2) = \mathcal{P}(v_1) + \mathcal{P}(v_2) P(v1​+v2​)=P(v1​)+P(v2​)

    • Note that the projection of two vector can cancel each other in some cases, in the sense that they points to different direction.

      In the above example, if we write v1=v1,1e1+v1,2e2v_1 = v_{1, 1} e_1 + v_{1, 2} e_2v1​=v1,1​e1​+v1,2​e2​, then P(v1,1e1)\mathcal{P} (v_{1, 1} e_1)P(v1,1​e1​) and P(v1,2e2)\mathcal{P} (v_{1,2} e_2)P(v1,2​e2​) points to opposite directions. This implies that we should give volume a sign. For example, we can define the direction pointed by purple vector points to be positive. The volume of the parallelogram increases if a vector’s projection moves along this direction and decrease otherwise.

  2. If v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​ are linearly independent, then the parallelotope is contained in a subspace with dimension smaller than nnn and should have volume zero.

    Intuitively, the parallelotope collapses to a lower dimension space. Examples include colinear vectors in two dimension case and the third vector lying in the hyperplane spanned by the other two in the three dimension case.
    Finally, we emphases an important case here:

f(...,vi,...,vj,...,)=0, if vi=vj,∀i,j∈[n],i≠jf(..., v_i,..., v_j, ... , ) = 0, \textbf{ if } v_i = v_j, \forall i, j \in [n], i \neq j f(...,vi​,...,vj​,...,)=0, if vi​=vj​,∀i,j∈[n],i=j

If we write

vi=vi,1e1+vi,2e2+...+vi,nenv_i = v_{i, 1} e_1 + v_{i, 2} e_2 + ... + v_{i, n} e_n vi​=vi,1​e1​+vi,2​e2​+...+vi,n​en​

for all i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], then by linearity

f(v1,v2,...,vn)=f(v1,1e1+v1,2e2+...+v1,nen,v2,1e1+v2,2e2+...+v2,nen,...vn,1e1+vn,2e2+...+vn,nen)=∑k1,k2,...,kn∈[n]v1,k1v2,k2...vn,knf(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)\begin{aligned} f(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n) &= f( v_{1, 1} e_1 + v_{1, 2} e_2 + ... + v_{1, n} e_n, \\ &\qquad v_{2, 1} e_1 + v_{2, 2} e_2 + ... + v_{2, n} e_n, \\ &\qquad ...\\ &\qquad v_{n, 1} e_1 + v_{n, 2} e_2 + ... + v_{n, n} e_n) \\ &= \sum_{k_1, k_2, ..., k_n \in [n]} v_{1, k_1} v_{2, k_2} ... v_{n, k_n} f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n}) \end{aligned} f(v1​,v2​,...,vn​)​=f(v1,1​e1​+v1,2​e2​+...+v1,n​en​,v2,1​e1​+v2,2​e2​+...+v2,n​en​,...vn,1​e1​+vn,2​e2​+...+vn,n​en​)=k1​,k2​,...,kn​∈[n]∑​v1,k1​​v2,k2​​...vn,kn​​f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​)​

Note that if ki=kjk_i = k_jki​=kj​ for i≠ji \neq ji=j, then f(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)=0f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n}) = 0f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​)=0. Therefore,

f(v1,v2,...,vn)=∑k is a permutationv1,k1v2,k2...vn,knf(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)f(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n) = \sum_{ k \text{ is a permutation} } v_{1, k_1} v_{2, k_2} ... v_{n, k_n} f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n}) f(v1​,v2​,...,vn​)=k is a permutation∑​v1,k1​​v2,k2​​...vn,kn​​f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​)

We are almost done. It is left to determined the value of f(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n})f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​), where k=(k1,k2,...,kn)k = (k_1, k_2, ..., k_n)k=(k1​,k2​,...,kn​) is a permutation of (1,2,....,n)(1, 2, ...., n)(1,2,....,n). Here we claim that is purely determined by the value of f(e1,e2,...,en)f(e_1, e_2, ..., e_n)f(e1​,e2​,...,en​). By conversion, we define

f(e1,e2,...,en)=1f(e_1, e_2, ..., e_n) = 1 f(e1​,e2​,...,en​)=1

Then we have the key lemma:

Lemma

f(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)=−1f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n}) = -1 f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​)=−1

if k1,k2,...,kn{k_1}, {k_2}, ..., {k_n}k1​,k2​,...,kn​ can be recovered to 1,2,...,n1, 2, ..., n1,2,...,n by odd number of neighboring swaps and

f(ek1,ek2,...,ekn)=1f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_n}) = 1 f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,ekn​​)=1

if k1,k2,...,kn{k_1}, {k_2}, ..., {k_n}k1​,k2​,...,kn​ can be recovered to 1,2,...,n1, 2, ..., n1,2,...,n by even number of neighboring swaps.

Proof.
The key is to prove that we swap two neighboring vectors, then the sign of the volume change:

f(ek1,ek2,...,eki,eki+1,...,ekn)=−f(ek1,ek2,...,eki+1,eki,...,ekn)f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_{i } }, e_{k_{i + 1} }, ..., e_{k_n}) = -f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_{i + 1 } }, e_{k_{i } }, ..., e_{k_n}) f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,eki​​,eki+1​​,...,ekn​​)=−f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,eki+1​​,eki​​,...,ekn​​)

This is because

f(ek1,ek2,...,eki+eki+1,eki+eki+1,...,ekn)=f(ek1,ek2,...,eki,eki+1,...,ekn)+f(ek1,ek2,...,eki+1,eki,...,ekn)=0\begin{aligned} f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_{i } } + e_{k_{i + 1} }, e_{k_{i } } + e_{k_{i + 1} }, ..., e_{k_n}) &= f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_{i } }, e_{k_{i + 1} }, ..., e_{k_n})\\ &\quad + f(e_{k_1}, e_{k_2}, ..., e_{k_{i + 1 } }, e_{k_{i } }, ..., e_{k_n}) \\ &= 0 \end{aligned} f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,eki​​+eki+1​​,eki​​+eki+1​​,...,ekn​​)​=f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,eki​​,eki+1​​,...,ekn​​)+f(ek1​​,ek2​​,...,eki+1​​,eki​​,...,ekn​​)=0​

□\square□

Cross Product

If we fix v2,v3,...,vnv_2, v_3, ..., v_nv2​,v3​,...,vn​, then det⁡(x,v2,...,vn):Rn→R\det(x, v_2, ..., v_n): \R^n \rightarrow \Rdet(x,v2​,...,vn​):Rn→R is a linear function. Then

det⁡(x,v2,...,vn)=∑i=1ndet⁡(xiei,v2,...,vn)=∑i=1nxidet⁡(ei,v2,...,vn)\begin{aligned} \det(x, v_2, ..., v_n) &= \sum_{i = 1}^n \det(x_i e_i, v_2, ..., v_n) \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^n x_i \det(e_i, v_2, ..., v_n) \end{aligned} det(x,v2​,...,vn​)​=i=1∑n​det(xi​ei​,v2​,...,vn​)=i=1∑n​xi​det(ei​,v2​,...,vn​)​

where xix_ixi​ is the i-th coordinator of xxx. If we write

d=<det(e1,v2,...,vn),det(e2,v2,...,vn),...,det(en,v2,...,vn)>d = \left< det(e_1, v_2, ..., v_n), det(e_2, v_2, ..., v_n), ..., det(e_n, v_2, ..., v_n)\right> d=⟨det(e1​,v2​,...,vn​),det(e2​,v2​,...,vn​),...,det(en​,v2​,...,vn​)⟩

Then

det⁡(x,v2,...,vn)=d⋅x\det(x, v_2, ..., v_n) = d \cdot x det(x,v2​,...,vn​)=d⋅x

Indeed, in a similar manner, we can prove that for any h:Rn×n→Rnh: \R^{n \times n} \rightarrow \R^nh:Rn×n→Rn linear function, there exists a vector h⃗\vec hh, such that

h(x)=h⃗⋅xh(x) = \vec h \cdot x h(x)=h⋅x

Conventionally, ddd is called the cross product of v2,...,vnv_2, ..., v_nv2​,...,vn​ is written as

d=v2×v3×...×vnd = v_2 \times v_3 \times ... \times v_n d=v2​×v3​×...×vn​

It has some interesting properties:

  1. ddd is perpendicular to the subspace spanned by v2,...,vnv_2, ..., v_nv2​,...,vn​, as d⋅vi=det⁡(vi,v2,...,vn)=0d \cdot v_i = \det(v_i, v_2, ..., v_n) = 0d⋅vi​=det(vi​,v2​,...,vn​)=0 for 2≤i≤n2 \le i \le n2≤i≤n.

  2. For any x∈Rnx \in \R^nx∈Rn, d⋅xd \cdot xd⋅x gives the signed volume of the parallelotope spanned by x,v2,...,vnx, v_2, ..., v_nx,v2​,...,vn​.

    • When n=2n = 2n=2, the length of ddd equals to that of v2v_2v2​.
    • When n=3n = 3n=3, the length of ddd equals to the area of the parallelogram spanned by v2,v3v_2, v_3v2​,v3​. Combined with the fact that ddd is perpendicular to v2,v3v_2, v_3v2​,v3​, we see why d⋅xd \cdot xd⋅x gives the volume of the parallelotope spanned by x,v2,v3x, v_2, v_3x,v2​,v3​: it takes the projection of xxx to the direction that is perpendicular to v2v_2v2​ and v3v_3v3​, scaled by a factor of the area spanned by v2v_2v2​ and v3v_3v3​.

  3. The direction given of ddd is given by right hand rule, when n=2n = 2n=2 or n=3n = 3n=3.

□\square□

Cramer’s Rule

Cramer’s rule is a formula for solving linear equations. In particular, given an invertible matrix A∈Rn×nA \in \R^{n \times n}A∈Rn×n, and vector b∈Rnb \in \R^nb∈Rn, then the solution for the equation

Ax=bAx = b Ax=b

is given by (∀i∈[n]\forall i \in [n]∀i∈[n]),

xi=det⁡(Ai)det⁡(A)x_i = \frac{\det(A_i) }{\det (A)} xi​=det(A)det(Ai​)​

where xix_ixi​ is the i-th coordinate of xxx and AiA_iAi​ is the matrix formed by replacing AAA’s the iii-th column by column vector bbb.

To understand the formula, we view AAA as a mapping T:Rn→RnT: \R^n \rightarrow \R^nT:Rn→Rn that takes ei(i∈[n])e_i (i \in [n])ei​(i∈[n]) to A[:,i]A[:,i]A[:,i], i.e.,

T(ei)=A[:,i]T(e_i) = A[:, i] T(ei​)=A[:,i]

where A[:,i]A[:, i]A[:,i] is the i-th column of AAA. The image of the hypercube

{∑i∈[n]λiei:λi∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]}\left\{ \sum_{i \in [n]} \lambda_i e_i : \lambda_i \in [0, 1], \forall i \in [n] \right\} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​i∈[n]∑​λi​ei​:λi​∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

is given as

{∑i∈[n]λiA[:,i]:λi∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]}\left\{ \sum_{i \in [n]} \lambda_i A[:, i] : \lambda_i \in [0, 1], \forall i \in [n] \right\} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​i∈[n]∑​λi​A[:,i]:λi​∈[0,1],∀i∈[n]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

Original the hypercube has volume 1. After the transformation it has volume det⁡(A)\det(A)det(A). One interesting fact about linear transformation is that it preserves volumes ratio. Define V(⋅)\mathbb{V}(\cdot)V(⋅) the volume of a parallelotope.

Fact. For any parallelotope PPP, its volume under transformation TTT is given by

det⁡(A)V(P)=V(T(P))\det(A) \mathbb{V}(P) = \mathbb{V}(T(P)) det(A)V(P)=V(T(P))

Now, we rewrite the Cramer’s rule as

det⁡(A)xi=det⁡(Ai)\det(A) x_i = \det(A_i) det(A)xi​=det(Ai​)

Its meaning is clear: there is a parallelotope PPP whose volume is xix_ixi​ and after the transformation it has volume det⁡(Ai)\det(A_i)det(Ai​).

It is left to verify that the parallelotope indeed exists.
We observe that det⁡(Ai)\det(A_i)det(Ai​) can be viewed as the volume of the following parallelotope formed by

{∑j∈[n],j≠iλjA[:,j]+λibi:λj∈[0,1],∀j,λi∈[0,1]}\left\{ \sum_{j \in [n], j \neq i} \lambda_j A[:, j] +\lambda_i b_i: \lambda_j \in [0, 1], \forall j, \lambda_i \in [0, 1] \right\} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​j∈[n],j=i∑​λj​A[:,j]+λi​bi​:λj​∈[0,1],∀j,λi​∈[0,1]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

But this parallel0tope is the image of

{∑j∈[n],j≠iλjej+λixi:λj∈[0,1],∀j,λi∈[0,1]}\left\{ \sum_{j \in [n], j \neq i} \lambda_j e_j +\lambda_i x_i: \lambda_j \in [0, 1], \forall j, \lambda_i \in [0, 1] \right\} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​j∈[n],j=i∑​λj​ej​+λi​xi​:λj​∈[0,1],∀j,λi​∈[0,1]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

as

T({∑j∈[n],j≠iλjej+λixi:λj∈[0,1],∀j,λi∈[0,1]})={∑j∈[n],j≠iλjT(ej)+λiT(xi):λj∈[0,1],∀j,λi∈[0,1]}={∑j∈[n],j≠iλjA[:,j]+λibi:λj∈[0,1],∀j,λi∈[0,1]}\begin{aligned} & T \left( \left\{ \sum_{j \in [n], j \neq i} \lambda_j e_j +\lambda_i x_i: \lambda_j \in [0, 1], \forall j, \lambda_i \in [0, 1] \right\} \right) \\ &= \left\{ \sum_{j \in [n], j \neq i} \lambda_j T(e_j) +\lambda_i T(x_i): \lambda_j \in [0, 1], \forall j, \lambda_i \in [0, 1] \right\} \\ &= \left\{ \sum_{j \in [n], j \neq i} \lambda_j A[:, j] +\lambda_i b_i: \lambda_j \in [0, 1], \forall j, \lambda_i \in [0, 1] \right\} \end{aligned} ​T⎝⎛​⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​j∈[n],j=i∑​λj​ej​+λi​xi​:λj​∈[0,1],∀j,λi​∈[0,1]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​⎠⎞​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​j∈[n],j=i∑​λj​T(ej​)+λi​T(xi​):λj​∈[0,1],∀j,λi​∈[0,1]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​j∈[n],j=i∑​λj​A[:,j]+λi​bi​:λj​∈[0,1],∀j,λi​∈[0,1]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​​

□\square□

Simplex

Posted on 2020-02-07 Edited on 2021-07-17

Simplex is the first systematically method for solving linear program via a sequence of Gaussian eliminations.
It was invented by George Dantzig in 1947 [1].
Algebraically, it converts the linear program from one slack form into to an equivalent one whose objective value does not decrease and possibly increase. It keeps going until the optimal is reached. Geometrically, it is a greedy search strategy that moves from a vertex of the feasible region to another one, with the objective value at the new vertex as least as good as or possibly improved over the previous one. It is an exponential algorithm, although most of time it does a lot better. In this blog we walk through a simple example to illustrate this.

In this case we are operating a factory with two products. Both product have 1 unit of profit. Making the products needs to use two kind of machine. Product one uses 1 hour of machine one and product two uses 2 hours of machine one. Further, product one uses 2 hours of machine two and product two uses 1 hour of machine two. Both machines operate at most 6 hours each day. We want to maximize our profit:

max⁡x1+x2s.t.x1+2x2≤62x1+x2≤6x1,x2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 + x_2 \\ &s.t. & x_1 + 2x_2 \le 6 \\ & & 2x_1 + x_2 \le 6 \\ & & x_1, x_2 \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​+x2​x1​+2x2​≤62x1​+x2​≤6x1​,x2​≥0​

It can be represented concisely in matrix form:

max⁡cTxs.t.Ax≤bx≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & c^T x \\ &s.t. & A x \le b \\ & & x \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​cTxAx≤bx≥0​

where

A=[1221],b=[66],c=[11],x=[x1x2],\begin{aligned} A = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{matrix} \right], \quad b = \left[ \begin{matrix} 6 \\ 6 \end{matrix} \right], \quad c = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{matrix} \right], \quad x = \left[ \begin{matrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{matrix} \right], \end{aligned} A=[12​21​],b=[66​],c=[11​],x=[x1​x2​​],​

We call the set of points that satisfy the constraints of the optimization problem the feasible region

P={x:Ax≤b,x≥0}P = \{x : Ax \le b, x \ge 0\} P={x:Ax≤b,x≥0}

It is obvious that the optimal is obtained at (2,2)(2, 2)(2,2), which gives the objective value 444. It is a vertex of the feasible region.

Slack Form

In general, it might not be obvious what the optimal point is. But if the elements of bbb are non-negative, the origin is a feasible point, from which we can begin our search. To make the search easier, we are going to introduce an additional number of variables, the slack variables s1,s2s_1, s_2s1​,s2​ and zzz that correspond to the constraints and objective value.

z=x1+x2s1=6−x1−2x2s2=6−2x1−x2\begin{aligned} z = & & x_1 &+x_2 \\ s_1 = &6 & -x_1 &-2x_2 \\ s_2 = &6 & -2x_1 &-x_2 \\ \end{aligned} z=s1​=s2​=​66​x1​−x1​−2x1​​+x2​−2x2​−x2​​

rewrite the optimization into slack form:

max⁡x1+x2=zs.t.x1+2x2+s1=62x1+x2+s2=6x1,x2,s1,s2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 &+x_2 & & &= z\\ &s.t. & x_1 &+2x_2 &+s_1 & &= 6 \\ & & 2x_1 &+x_2 & &+s_2 &= 6 \\ & & x_1, &x_2, &s_1 &,s_2 &\ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​x1​2x1​x1​,​+x2​+2x2​+x2​x2​,​+s1​s1​​+s2​,s2​​=z=6=6≥0​

They are called slacks variables because they correspond how much slack you have in the inequalities in the original problem. For this slack form, we also call s1s_1s1​ and s2s_2s2​ basic variables, and the original variables non-basic variables.

Now the feasible region FFF is considered as the intersection of the two subspaces

F={x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}F = \{x : Ax = b \} \cap \{ x \ge 0 \} F={x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}

We can represent the LP in slack form even more concisely in a table:

1210∣62101∣61100∣0\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​

where the last column denotes the objective function. This example has a trivial starting point : (0,0,6,6)(0, 0, 6, 6)(0,0,6,6). It is called a basic solution in which all non-basic variables are set to zero. It can be read from the tabular form: the identity matrix correspond to basic variables, and (s1,s2)=b(s_1, s_2) = b(s1​,s2​)=b.

Pivoting

Look at the original LP:

max⁡x1+x2=zs.t.x1+2x2+s1=62x1+x2+s2=6x1,x2,s1,s2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 &+x_2 & & &= z\\ &s.t. & x_1 &+2x_2 &+s_1 & &= 6 \\ & & 2x_1 &+x_2 & &+s_2 &= 6 \\ & & x_1, &x_2, &s_1 &,s_2 &\ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​x1​2x1​x1​,​+x2​+2x2​+x2​x2​,​+s1​s1​​+s2​,s2​​=z=6=6≥0​

As we would like to maximize the objective, we would like to increase the value of x1x_1x1​ or x2x_2x2​ as much as possible. Suppose we just increase one variable at a time. For example, we can increase variable x1x_1x1​ and keep the value of x2x_2x2​ to be 000.

How much can we increase x1x_1x1​? After increasing x1x_1x1​, we need to maintain the inequality constraints:

x1+s1=62x1+s2=6x_1 + s_1 = 6 \\ 2 x_1 + s_2 = 6 x1​+s1​=62x1​+s2​=6

The values of s1s_1s1​ and s2s_2s2​ decrease as x1x_1x1​ increases. By they can be drop below 000. The maximum possible increases of x1x_1x1​ is bounded by 6/2=36 / 2 = 36/2=3. If we set x1=3x_1 = 3x1​=3, s1=6−x1=3s_1 = 6 - x_1 = 3s1​=6−x1​=3 and s2=6−2x1=0s_2 = 6 - 2x_1 = 0s2​=6−2x1​=0.

Note that x1x_1x1​ increases from 000 to 333 and s2s_2s2​ decreases from 666 to 000. This process is called pivoting.

How do we perform pivoting in the tabular form? By the replacement we have just performed – normalizing the second row, and using it to eliminate all other elements in the first column.

Recall the original table:

1210∣62101∣61100∣0\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​

We divide the second row by a factor of 2 to normalize it, and subtract the first and third row by the second row

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣301/20−1/2∣−3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \hline 0 && 1/2 && 0 && -1/2 && \mid -3 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​3/21/21/2​​100​​−1/21/2−1/2​​∣3∣3∣−3​​

Observe the first two rows of the tabular form:

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \end{aligned} 01​​3/21/2​​10​​−1/21/2​​∣3∣3​

If we set x2=0x_2 = 0x2​=0 and s2=0s_2 = 0s2​=0, the constraints they implies becomes

s1=3x1=3s_1 = 3 \\ x_1 = 3 s1​=3x1​=3

Again the unity columns correspond to non-zero elements and we can read the solution from the tabular form.

Correctness of Pivoting

Before we continue our search on the tabular form, we need to show that pivoting is correct in the sense that, after pivoting, the tabular form represents the same optimization.

In particular, we need to guarantee that the feasible regions are the same and the objective function are equivalent defined on the feasible regions.

We focus on the extended matrix that represents the constraints:

Aˉ=[A,b]=[1210∣62101∣6]\bar A = [A, b] = \left[\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \end{aligned}\right] Aˉ=[A,b]=[12​​21​​10​​01​​∣6∣6​]

FACT 1. Doing a row replacement on Aˉ\bar AAˉ does not change FFF, where row replacement is defined as

Aˉ[i:]←Aˉ[i:]+k⋅Aˉ[j:]\bar A[i: ] \leftarrow \bar A[i: ] + k \cdot \bar A[j: ] Aˉ[i:]←Aˉ[i:]+k⋅Aˉ[j:]

i.e., adding kkk times the jjj-th row to the iii-th row, for i≠j,k∈Ri \neq j, k \in Ri=j,k∈R.

To see this, denote FFF and F′F'F′ the sets before and after the replacement respectively. F=F′F = F'F=F′ implies that each point xxx belonging to FFF belongs to F′F'F′, and vice-versa. Specifically, the row replacement corresponds to left multiplying Aˉ\bar AAˉ by a matrix

E(i,j),k≐[11...k1...1]\begin{aligned} E_{(i,j), k} \doteq \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & \\ & 1 \\ & & \quad... \\ & & k & 1 \\ & & & & ... \\ & & & & & 1 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} E(i,j),k​≐⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​1​1​...k​1​...​1​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

which is a diagonal matrix with an additional kkk in the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) position. It is invertible with inverse matrix

E(i,j),−k≐[11...−k1...1]\begin{aligned} E_{(i,j), -k} \doteq \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & \\ & 1 \\ & & \quad... \\ & & -k & 1 \\ & & & & ... \\ & & & & & 1 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} E(i,j),−k​≐⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​1​1​...−k​1​...​1​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

The previous claim becomes {x:E(i,j),kAx=E(i,j),kb}={x:Ax=b}\{ x : E_{(i, j), k} A x = E_{(i, j), k} b \} = \{ x : A x = b \}{x:E(i,j),k​Ax=E(i,j),k​b}={x:Ax=b}.

But wait. Why do we subtract the last row from the second one? Fact 1 has justified the replacement operation on Aˉ\bar AAˉ, but not on the objective coefficients ccc (the last row in the tabular form). To illustrate the meaning of the operation, recall that

x1+x2+0⋅s1+0⋅s2=zx_1 + x_2 + 0 \cdot s_1 + 0 \cdot s_2 = z x1​+x2​+0⋅s1​+0⋅s2​=z

Hence zzz is the value of the objective function. After normalizing the second row, it becomes

x1+1/2x2+0s1+1/2s2=3x_1 + 1 / 2 x_2 + 0 s_1 + 1/2 s_2 = 3 \\ x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​+1/2s2​=3

The constraint holds for any feasible point of the linear programming. Therefore,

z−3=(x1+x2+0s1+0s2)−(x1+1/2x2+0s1+1/2s2)=0x1+1/2x2+0s1−1/2s2⇔z=0x1+1/2x2+0s1−1/2s2+3\begin{aligned} z - 3 &= (x_1 + x_2 + 0 s_1 + 0 s_2) - (x_1 + 1 / 2 x_2 + 0 s_1 + 1/2 s_2) \\ &= 0x_1 + 1/2x_2 + 0s_1 - 1/2 s_2 \\ &\Leftrightarrow \\ z &= 0x_1 + 1/2x_2 + 0s_1 - 1/2 s_2 + 3 \end{aligned} z−3z​=(x1​+x2​+0s1​+0s2​)−(x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​+1/2s2​)=0x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​−1/2s2​⇔=0x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​−1/2s2​+3​

The last −3-3−3 in the table is the inverse constant in the objective functions after the replacement of variable.

Back to our search

To improve the current solution further, we note that the coefficient of x2x_2x2​ is positive. We can increase the value of x2x_2x2​. The maximum increase is given by min⁡{3/(1/2),3/(3/2)}=2\min \{ 3 / (1 / 2), 3 / (3/ 2) \} = 2min{3/(1/2),3/(3/2)}=2, determined by the first row:

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣301/20−1/2∣−3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \hline 0 && 1/2 && 0 && -1/2 && \mid -3 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​3/21/21/2​​100​​−1/21/2−1/2​​∣3∣3∣−3​​

To make the change explicitly, we perform elimination by the first row

012/3−1/3∣210−1/32/3∣200−1/3−1/3∣−4\begin{aligned} 0 && 1 && 2/3 && -1/3 && \mid 2 \\ 1 && 0 && -1/3 && 2/3 && \mid 2 \\ \hline 0 && 0 && -1/3 && -1/3 && \mid -4 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​100​​2/3−1/3−1/3​​−1/32/3−1/3​​∣2∣2∣−4​​

which give solution x=(2,2,0,0)x = (2, 2, 0, 0)x=(2,2,0,0) and objective value 444. It is indeed optimal solution for the problem, as all coefficients of the optimization are non-positive.

Optimality Condition and Strong Duality

We investigate the result deeper by viewing the initial tabular form in abbreviation as

[AI∣bcT0∣0]\left[ \begin{matrix} A \quad I \mid b \\ c^T \quad 0 \mid 0 \end{matrix} \right] [AI∣bcT0∣0​]

The series of mmm Gaussian elimination can be interpreted as left multiplying a matrix:

[R0−yT1]≐Em...E3E2E1\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \doteq E_m...E_3 E_2 E_1 \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​]≐Em​...E3​E2​E1​​

where each EjE_jEj​ ( 1≤j≤m1 \le j \le m1≤j≤m) matrix is invertible and represents a Gaussian elimination, i.e., if we left multiple a matrix by EjE_jEj​, it is equivalent to perform Gaussian elimination on the matrix. The matrix product Em...E3E2E1E_m...E_3 E_2 E_1Em​...E3​E2​E1​ has the form

[R0−yT1]\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​]​

because we never use the last row to eliminate the other rows.

Now:

[R0−yT1][AI∣bcT0∣0]=[RAR∣Rb−yTA+cT−yT∣−yTb]\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} & A & I \mid b \\ & c^T & 0 \mid 0 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[ \begin{matrix} & RA & R & \mid & Rb \\ & -y^TA+c^T & -y^T &\mid & -y^T b \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​][​AcT​I∣b0∣0​]=[​RA−yTA+cT​R−yT​∣∣​Rb−yTb​]​

In our example,

1210∣62101∣61100∣0⇒...⇒012/3−1/3∣210−1/32/3∣200−1/3−1/3∣−4\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} \Rightarrow ... \Rightarrow \begin{aligned} 0 && 1 && 2/3 && -1/3 && \mid 2 \\ 1 && 0 && -1/3 && 2/3 && \mid 2 \\ \hline 0 && 0 && -1/3 && -1/3 && \mid -4 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​⇒...⇒010​​100​​2/3−1/3−1/3​​−1/32/3−1/3​​∣2∣2∣−4​​

we have

R=[2/3−1/3−1/32/3]yT=[−1/3,−1/3]R = \begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} 2 / 3 & -1 / 3 \\ -1 / 3 & 2 /3 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} \qquad y^T = [ -1 / 3, -1 / 3] R=[2/3−1/3​−1/32/3​]​yT=[−1/3,−1/3]

The optimality condition of simplex algorithm implies that

−yTA+cT≤0yT≤0yTb=cTx\begin{aligned} -y^T A + c^T &\le 0 \\ y^T &\le 0 \\ y^T b &= c^T x \end{aligned} −yTA+cTyTyTb​≤0≤0=cTx​

This is the optimal solution for the dual program of the primal:

min⁡ bTy,s.t.,ATy≥c,yT≥0\min \ b^T y, \qquad s.t., A^T y \ge c, \quad y^T \ge 0 min bTy,s.t.,ATy≥c,yT≥0

If simplex algorithm stops, it implies strong duality holds:

  • The optimal value of the primal program equals to the optimal one of the dual program, assuming that both values exist and are bounded.

Geometric Interpretation

In the beginning we claim that the simplex algorithm move from one vertex to another. We prove it rigorously in this section. First we need a few definitions:

Vertex

A vertex is a point v∈Fv \in Fv∈F, such that ∄v1,v2∈F,v1≠v2\nexists v_1, v_2 \in F, v_1 \neq v_2∄v1​,v2​∈F,v1​=v2​ and λ∈(0,1)\lambda \in (0, 1)λ∈(0,1), s.t., v=λv1+(1−λ)v2v = \lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2v=λv1​+(1−λ)v2​.

In other words, vvv is a vertex of FFF if it is not contained in a line segment of PPP.

Theorem. If LP has an optimal solution, then it has an optimal solution that is a vertex of its feasible set.

Proof. Denote vvv the optimal solution of the LP with maximum number of zero components. If vvv is not a vertex, then ∃v1,v2≠v,v1,v2∈F\exists v_1, v_2 \neq v, v_1, v_2 \in F∃v1​,v2​=v,v1​,v2​∈F and λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, such that λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v.

As vvv is optimal, we have cTv≥cTv1c^T v \ge c^T v_1cTv≥cTv1​ and cTv≥cTv2c^T v \ge c^T v_2cTv≥cTv2​. By λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v, it concludes that cTv=cTv1=cTv2c_T v = c^T v_1 = c^T v_2cT​v=cTv1​=cTv2​.

Define I={i:v[i]>0}I = \{ i : v[i] > 0 \}I={i:v[i]>0}. As v1≥0,v2≥0v_1 \ge 0, v_2 \ge 0v1​≥0,v2​≥0 and λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v so that for i≠Ii \neq Ii=I, v1[i]=v2[i]=v[i]=0v_1[i] = v_2[i] = v[i] = 0v1​[i]=v2​[i]=v[i]=0.

But AIv1[I]=AIv2[I]=bA_I v_1[I] = A_I v_2[I] = bAI​v1​[I]=AI​v2​[I]=b. Let x=ϵ(v1−v2)+vx = \epsilon (v_1 - v_2) + vx=ϵ(v1​−v2​)+v.

  1. xxx is feasible, for small enough ϵ\epsilonϵ.
  2. xxx is optimal, since cTx=ϵcT(v1−v2)+cTv=cTvc^T x= \epsilon c^T (v_1 - v_2) + c^T v = c^T vcTx=ϵcT(v1​−v2​)+cTv=cTv.
  3. xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0 for i∉Ii \notin Ii∈/I.

We can find some ϵ\epsilonϵ (either positive or false) to make xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0 for some i∈Ii \in Ii∈I. Now xxx contains more zeros than vvv, a contradiction. □\square□

Basic Solution

A solution xxx of Ax=bAx = bAx=b is called a basic solution if {Ai:xi≠0}\{A_i : x_i \neq 0 \}{Ai​:xi​=0} (columns in AAA that correspond to non-zero components in xxx ) are linearly independent.

Basic Feasible Solution

A basic solution xxx is called basic feasible solution if x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, i.e., x∈{x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}x \in \{ x : Ax = b\} \cap \{ x \ge 0 \}x∈{x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}.

With respect to the feasible region of LP in slack form, the vertices have have following property:

Lemma:. A point v∈F={x:Ax=b}∩{x:x≥0}v \in F = \{x : Ax = b\} \cap \{ x: x \ge 0\}v∈F={x:Ax=b}∩{x:x≥0} is a vertex of FFF if and only if it is a basic feasible solution. Here A∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈RmA \in R^{m \times n}, x \in R^n, b \in R^{m}A∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈Rm and rank(A)=mrank(A) = mrank(A)=m (otherwise some row constraints of the Ax=bAx = bAx=b are redundant).

Proof: Denote SSS the set of indices of positive components in vvv and ASA_SAS​ the set of

Only if: If ASA_SAS​ does not have full column rank, then ∃u∈R∣S∣\exists u \in R^{|S|}∃u∈R∣S∣, such that ASu=0A_S u = 0AS​u=0. Then for small enough ϵ∈R,ϵ>0\epsilon \in R, \epsilon > 0ϵ∈R,ϵ>0,
both v+ϵuv + \epsilon uv+ϵu and v−ϵuv - \epsilon uv−ϵu are feasible point in FFF. Now v=0.5(v+ϵu)+0.5(v−ϵu)v = 0.5(v + \epsilon u) + 0.5(v - \epsilon u)v=0.5(v+ϵu)+0.5(v−ϵu), a contradiction.

If: As columns of ASA_SAS​ are linearly independent, the only solution of to ASxS=0A_S x_S = 0AS​xS​=0 is given by xS=0x_S = 0xS​=0. Hence, vSv_SvS​ is now the unique solution to ASvS=bA_S v_S = bAS​vS​=b. If vvv is not a vertex, ∃v1,v2,λ\exists v_1, v_2, \lambda∃v1​,v2​,λ, such that v=λv1+(1−λ)v2v = \lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2v=λv1​+(1−λ)v2​. But in this case we must have v1=v2=vv_1 = v_2 = vv1​=v2​=v, as (v1)S=(v2)S=vS(v_1)_S = (v_2)_S = v_S(v1​)S​=(v2​)S​=vS​ and (v1)Sˉ=(v2)Sˉ=vSˉ=0(v_1)_{\bar S} = (v_2)_{\bar S} = v_{\bar S} = 0(v1​)Sˉ​=(v2​)Sˉ​=vSˉ​=0. A contradiction.

■\blacksquare■.

Corollary: The simplex algorithm moves from vertex to vertex.

Proof: The positive components in the solution correspond to the columns in the identity matrix in the tabular form of simplex, which are linearly independent.

Correctness of Simplex (TO FINISH)

Though not shown in the example, there are two issue associated with simplex algorithm.

  1. How do we find an initial solution? If there are negative component in bbb, then x=0∧s=bx = 0 \wedge s = bx=0∧s=b is not a feasible solution.
  2. How do we guarantee that simplex terminates?

In the previous example, at each step we choose to increase the variable with largest coefficient. In some rare cases, this results in a loop of the algorithm.

One method for avoiding looping is called Bland’s rule:

  1. If there is a positive coefficient in the objective function, choose the one with largest coefficient.
  2. If there are multiple rows with tight constraints, choose the one with largest coefficient.

Theorem. Blands’ rule guarantees that the algorithm stops.

Proof. Suppose that on the contrary, the algorithm loops. Denote B1,B2,...,BkB_1, B_2, ..., B_kB1​,B2​,...,Bk​ the set of basis in the loop. In each base, there is entering variable and one leaving variable. Every variable that leaves the base must enter another base later. We called these variable fickle variables. Denote xtx_txt​ the fickle variable with the largest index.

  1. DDD the dictionary that xtx_txt​ leaves the base, and xex_exe​ the variable that enters the base.
  2. D′D'D′ the dictionary that xtx_txt​ enters the base again.

D=IAN∣b0cN∣α⇒...⇒D′=RRAN∣RbyTyTAN+cN∣yTb+αD = \begin{aligned} I && A_N && \mid b \\ \hline 0 && c_N && \mid \alpha \\ \end{aligned} \Rightarrow ... \Rightarrow D' = \begin{aligned} R && R A_N && \mid R b \\ \hline y^T && y^T A_N + c_N && \mid y^T b + \alpha \\ \end{aligned} D=I0​​AN​cN​​​∣b∣α​​⇒...⇒D′=RyT​​RAN​yTAN​+cN​​​∣Rb∣yTb+α​​

We have

ce′=ce+yTAN[:,e]c_e' = c_e + y^T A_N[:, e] ce′​=ce​+yTAN​[:,e]

  1. xex_exe​ is the entering variable in DDD, therefore ce>0c_e > 0ce​>0.
  2. xtx_txt​ is the entering variable in D′D'D′, and e<te < te<t, by the definition of xtx_txt​, we have xe′≤0x_e' \le 0xe′​≤0.
  3. Hence, yTAN[:,e]=ce′−ce<0y^T A_N[:, e] = c_e' - c_e < 0yTAN​[:,e]=ce′​−ce​<0.
  4. ∃i,s.t.,yiAi,e<0\exists i, s.t., y_i A_{i, e} < 0∃i,s.t.,yi​Ai,e​<0. Then yi≠0y_i \neq 0yi​=0, and xix_ixi​ is fickle. By definition, i<ti < ti<t. But xix_ixi​ is not entering D′D'D′, we know that yi<0y_i < 0yi​<0.
  5. Ai,e>0A_{i, e} > 0Ai,e​>0. But since xix_ixi​ is fickle, we have bi=0b_i = 0bi​=0. In this case, xix_ixi​ is chosen in preference to xtx_txt​. A contradiction.

Reference
